15.64.text: So, before I became a dermatologist,

20.60.text: as most dermatologists do in Britain.

22.82.text: At the end of that time, I went off to Australia,

26.76.text: What you learn when you go to Australia

28.88.text: is the Australians are very competitive.

31.61.text: And they are not magnanimous in victory.

35.73.text: "You pommies, you can't play cricket, rugby."

42.61.text: and we have each week what's called a journal club,

45.15.text: when you'd sit down with the other doctors

47.60.text: and you'd study a scientific paper

51.56.text: And after week one, it was about cardiovascular mortality,

54.31.text: a dry subject -- how many people die of heart disease,

59.38.text: And they were competitive about this:

61.35.text: "You pommies, your rates of heart disease are shocking."

64.45.text: And of course, they were right.

66.35.text: Australians have about a third less heart disease than we do --

70.33.text: less deaths from heart attacks, heart failure, less strokes --

76.18.text: And of course they said this was because of

77.87.text: their fine moral standing, their exercise,

79.93.text: because they're Australians and we're weedy pommies, and so on.

84.00.text: But it's not just Australia that has better health than Britain.

89.03.text: Within Britain, there is a gradient of health --

92.56.text: and this is what's called standardized mortality,

96.58.text: This is looking at data from the paper about 20 years ago,

101.40.text: Comparing your rates of dying 50 degrees north --

104.49.text: that's the South, that's London and places --

110.11.text: the bad news is that's here, Glasgow.

112.50.text: I'm from Edinburgh. Worse news, that's even Edinburgh.

119.47.text: So what accounts for this horrible space here

122.77.text: between us up here in southern Scotland

127.41.text: deep-fried Mars bars, chips -- the Glasgow diet.

131.44.text: But this graph is after taking into account

134.23.text: all of these known risk factors.

136.29.text: This is after accounting for smoking, social class, diet,

140.06.text: all those other known risk factors.

141.80.text: We are left with this missing space

144.03.text: of increased deaths the further north you go.

147.89.text: Now, sunlight, of course, comes into this.

150.52.text: And vitamin D has had a great deal of press,

152.84.text: and a lot of people get concerned about it.

154.85.text: And we need vitamin D. It's now a requirement that children have a certain amount.

158.84.text: My grandmother grew up in Glasgow,

161.07.text: back in the 1920s and '30s when rickets was a real problem

164.66.text: and cod liver oil was brought in.

166.85.text: And that really prevented the rickets that used to be common in this city.

170.80.text: And I as a child was fed cod liver oil by my grandmother.

174.72.text: I distinctly -- nobody forgets cod liver oil.

177.74.text: But an association: The higher people's blood levels of vitamin D are,

182.52.text: the less heart disease they have, the less cancer.

185.85.text: There seems to be a lot of data suggesting that vitamin D is very good for you.

189.69.text: And it is, to prevent rickets and so on.

191.99.text: But if you give people vitamin D supplements,

194.71.text: you don't change that high rate of heart disease.

198.14.text: And the evidence for it preventing cancers is not yet great.

201.87.text: So what I'm going to suggest is that vitamin D is not the only story in town.

206.72.text: It's not the only reason preventing heart disease.

210.04.text: High vitamin D levels, I think, are a marker for sunlight exposure,

214.40.text: and sunlight exposure, in methods I'm going to show,

220.06.text: Anyway, I came back from Australia,

222.02.text: and despite the obvious risks to my health, I moved to Aberdeen.

228.07.text: Now, in Aberdeen, I started my dermatology training.

231.22.text: But I also became interested in research,

233.16.text: and in particular I became interested in this substance, nitric oxide.

236.34.text: Now these three guys up here,

239.28.text: won the Nobel Prize for medicine back in 1998.

242.55.text: And they were the first people to describe

244.69.text: this new chemical transmitter, nitric oxide.

248.03.text: What nitric oxide does is it dilates blood vessels,

251.06.text: so it lowers your blood pressure.

252.93.text: It also dilates the coronary arteries, so it stops angina.

257.10.text: And what was remarkable about it

258.48.text: was in the past when we think of chemical messengers within the body,

262.55.text: we thought of complicated things like estrogen and insulin,

267.19.text: Very complex processes with very complex chemicals

270.49.text: that fit into very complex receptors.

272.78.text: And here's this incredibly simple molecule,

275.14.text: a nitrogen and an oxygen that are stuck together,

278.48.text: and yet these are hugely important for [unclear] our low blood pressure,

283.11.text: for neurotransmission, for many, many things,

289.11.text: And I started doing research, and we found, very excitingly,

292.42.text: that the skin produces nitric oxide.

295.03.text: So it's not just in the cardiovascular system it arises.

299.79.text: Well, having found that and published that,

301.66.text: I thought, well, what's it doing?

303.71.text: How do you have low blood pressure in your skin?

305.19.text: It's not the heart. What do you do?

307.28.text: So I went off to the States, as many people do if they're going to do research,

311.35.text: and I spent a few years in Pittsburgh. This is Pittsburgh.

315.09.text: And I was interested in these really complex systems.

317.70.text: We thought that maybe nitric oxide affected cell death,

321.75.text: and how cells survive, and their resistance to other things.

324.23.text: And I first off started work in cell culture, growing cells,

327.59.text: and then I was using knockout mouse models --

329.71.text: mice that couldn't make the gene.

331.45.text: We worked out a mechanism, which -- NO was helping cells survive.

335.86.text: And I then moved back to Edinburgh.

339.68.text: And in Edinburgh, the experimental animal we use is the medical student.

342.46.text: It's a species close to human,

346.42.text: They're free, you don't shave them, they feed themselves,

349.88.text: and nobody pickets your office saying,

354.40.text: So they're really an ideal model.

359.62.text: was that we couldn't reproduce in man the data we had shown in mice.

364.24.text: It seemed we couldn't turn off the production

367.48.text: of nitric oxide in the skin of humans.

370.56.text: We put on creams that blocked the enzyme that made it,

373.35.text: we injected things. We couldn't turn off the nitric oxide.

377.74.text: And the reason for this, it turned out, after two or three years' work,

381.00.text: was that in the skin we have huge stores

385.05.text: not of nitric oxide, because nitric oxide is a gas,

388.14.text: and it's released -- (Poof!) -- and in a few seconds it's away,

391.29.text: but it can be turned into these forms of nitric oxide --

399.56.text: and your skin has got really large stores of NO.

403.72.text: And we then thought to ourselves, with those big stores,

406.54.text: I wonder if sunlight might activate those stores

409.86.text: and release them from the skin,

411.60.text: where the stores are about 10 times as big as what's in the circulation.

414.99.text: Could the sun activate those stores into the circulation,

417.83.text: and there in the circulation do its good things for your cardiovascular system?

425.60.text: so what we did was we thought

426.90.text: we'd have to expose our experimental animals to sunlight.

430.43.text: And so what we did was we took a bunch of volunteers

434.51.text: and we exposed them to ultraviolet light.

437.21.text: So these are kind of sunlamps.

438.94.text: Now, what we were careful to do was,

441.63.text: vitamin D is made by ultraviolet B rays

444.59.text: and we wanted to separate our story from the vitamin D story.

448.57.text: So we used ultraviolet A, which doesn't make vitamin D.

452.42.text: When we put people under a lamp

454.70.text: for the equivalent of about 30 minutes of sunshine in summer in Edinburgh,

459.77.text: what we produced was, we produced a rise

464.31.text: So we put patients with these subjects under the UV,

467.15.text: and their NO levels do go up,

469.57.text: and their blood pressure goes down.

471.71.text: Not by much, as an individual level,

474.08.text: but enough at a population level

476.45.text: to shift the rates of heart disease in a whole population.

480.17.text: And when we shone UV at them,

482.59.text: or when we warmed them up to the same level as the lamps,

486.26.text: but didn't actually let the rays hit the skin, this didn't happen.

489.52.text: So this seems to be a feature of ultraviolet rays hitting the skin.

496.65.text: This appeared to be more marked in older people.

499.80.text: I'm not sure exactly how much.

501.41.text: One of the subjects here was my mother-in-law,

503.19.text: and clearly I do not know her age.

506.14.text: But certainly in people older than my wife,

509.57.text: this appears to be a more marked effect.

512.70.text: And the other thing I should mention

513.96.text: was there was no change in vitamin D.

516.01.text: This is separate from vitamin D.

518.13.text: So vitamin D is good for you -- it stops rickets,

519.67.text: it prevents calcium metabolism, important stuff.

521.91.text: But this is a separate mechanism from vitamin D.

524.94.text: Now, one of the problems with looking at blood pressure

527.52.text: is your body does everything it can

529.07.text: to keep your blood pressure at the same place.

530.65.text: If your leg is chopped off and you lose blood,

532.30.text: your body will clamp down, increase the heart rate,

535.20.text: do everything it can to keep your blood pressure up.

537.43.text: That is an absolutely fundamental physiological principle.

542.21.text: is we've moved on to looking at blood vessel dilatation.

545.87.text: So we've measured -- this is again,

547.36.text: notice no tail and hairless, this is a medical student.

552.69.text: In the arm, you can measure blood flow in the arm

555.31.text: by how much it swells up as some blood flows into it.

558.54.text: And what we've shown is that doing a sham irradiation --

562.02.text: this is the thick line here --

563.49.text: this is shining UV on the arm so it warms up

565.89.text: but keeping it covered so the rays don't hit the skin.

568.71.text: There is no change in blood flow, in dilatation of the blood vessels.

574.47.text: during the UV and for an hour after it,

577.82.text: there is dilation of the blood vessels.

579.92.text: This is the mechanism by which you lower blood pressure,

582.52.text: by which you dilate the coronary arteries also,

584.90.text: to let the blood be supplied with the heart.

586.61.text: So here, further data that ultraviolet -- that's sunlight --

591.00.text: has benefits on the blood flow and the cardiovascular system.

595.88.text: So we thought we'd just kind of model --

598.22.text: Different amounts of UV hit different parts of the Earth at different times of year,

604.47.text: so you can actually work out those stores of nitric oxide --

608.50.text: the nitrates, nitrites, nitrosothiols in the skin --

613.62.text: Different wavelengths of light have different activities of doing that.

617.45.text: So you can look at the wavelengths of light that do that.

619.53.text: And you can look -- So, if you live on the equator, the sun comes straight overhead,

623.51.text: it comes through a very thin bit of atmosphere.

625.33.text: In winter or summer, it's the same amount of light.

627.77.text: If you live up here, in summer

630.28.text: the sun is coming fairly directly down,

632.94.text: but in winter it's coming through a huge amount of atmosphere,

636.24.text: and much of the ultraviolet is weeded out,

639.46.text: and the range of wavelengths that hit the Earth

641.82.text: are different from summer to winter.

644.14.text: So what you can do is you can multiply those data

648.08.text: and you can calculate how much nitric oxide

651.26.text: would be released from the skin into the circulation.

654.43.text: Now, if you're on the equator here --

656.43.text: that's these two lines here, the red line and the purple line --

659.86.text: the amount of nitric oxide that's released is the area under the curve,

664.26.text: it's the area in this space here.

666.29.text: So if you're on the equator, December or June,

668.98.text: you've got masses of NO being released from the skin.

672.24.text: So Ventura is in southern California.

674.70.text: In summer, you might as well be at the equator.

676.92.text: It's great. Lots of NO is released.

678.98.text: Ventura mid-winter, well, there's still a decent amount.

682.92.text: Edinburgh in summer, the area beneath the curve is pretty good,

686.88.text: but Edinburgh in winter, the amount of NO that can be released

691.10.text: is next to nothing, tiny amounts.

696.76.text: We're still working at this story,

698.35.text: we're still developing it, we're still expanding it.

701.91.text: We think it probably accounts for a lot of the north-south health divide within Britain,

708.82.text: well, we know that the skin has got very large stores

711.71.text: of nitric oxide as these various other forms.

713.93.text: We suspect a lot of these come from diet,

718.08.text: has a lot of these nitric oxides that we think go to the skin.

721.40.text: We think they're then stored in the skin,

723.54.text: and we think the sunlight releases this

725.94.text: where it has generally beneficial effects.

728.58.text: And this is ongoing work, but dermatologists --

732.77.text: My day job is saying to people, "You've got skin cancer,

735.30.text: it's caused by sunlight, don't go in the sun."

737.18.text: I actually think a far more important message

739.92.text: is that there are benefits as well as risks to sunlight.

743.34.text: Yes, sunlight is the major alterable risk factor for skin cancer,

749.10.text: but deaths from heart disease are a hundred times higher

753.92.text: And I think that we need to be more aware of,

756.57.text: and we need to find the risk-benefit ratio.

760.12.text: and how can we finesse this best for our general health?

764.32.text: So, thank you very much indeed.
